questions.question: What is Angular?
questions.answer: A TypeScript-based open-source web application framework led by the Angular Team at Google.

questions.question: What is the difference between Angular and AngularJS?
questions.answer: AngularJS (v1) is JS-based with controllers/scopes. Angular (v2+) is TS-based, component-oriented, and uses a hierarchy of components.

questions.question: What are the key building blocks of an Angular application?
questions.answer: Modules, Components, Templates, Metadata, Data Binding, Directives, Services, and Dependency Injection.

questions.question: What is a Component in Angular?
questions.answer: A class with the @Component decorator that controls a patch of screen called a view.

questions.question: What is a Template?
questions.answer: A form of HTML that tells Angular how to render the component.

questions.question: What is a Module (NgModule)?
questions.answer: A container for a cohesive block of code dedicated to an application domain, a workflow, or a closely related set of capabilities.

questions.question: What is Data Binding?
questions.answer: A mechanism for coordinating parts of a template with parts of a component.

questions.question: What is Interpolation?
questions.answer: One-way data binding from component to view using double curly braces {{ }}.

questions.question: What is Property Binding?
questions.answer: One-way data binding from component property to a target element property using square brackets [ ].

questions.question: What is Event Binding?
questions.answer: One-way data binding from a target element event to a component method using parentheses ( ).

questions.question: What is Two-Way Binding?
questions.answer: Combines property and event binding using the banana-in-a-box syntax [(ngModel)].

questions.question: What is a Directive?
questions.answer: A class with a @Directive decorator that adds behavior to elements in the DOM.

questions.question: Difference between Component and Directive?
questions.answer: A Component is a Directive with a template.

questions.question: What are Structural Directives?
questions.answer: Directives that change the DOM layout by adding and removing DOM elements (e.g., *ngIf, *ngFor).

questions.question: What are Attribute Directives?
questions.answer: Directives that change the appearance or behavior of an element (e.g., ngClass, ngStyle).

questions.question: What is Dependency Injection (DI)?
questions.answer: A design pattern in which a class requests dependencies from external sources rather than creating them.

questions.question: What is a Service?
questions.answer: A broad category encompassing any value, function, or feature that an app needs, typically a class with a narrow, well-defined purpose.

questions.question: What is the lifecycle of a component?
questions.answer: A sequence of steps (hooks) from creation to destruction (e.g., ngOnInit, ngOnDestroy).

questions.question: What is ngOnInit?
questions.answer: A lifecycle hook called once after the first ngOnChanges.

questions.question: What is ngOnDestroy?
questions.answer: A lifecycle hook called immediately before Angular destroys the directive or component.

questions.question: What is ViewEncapsulation?
questions.answer: Defines whether the template styles affect the whole application or just the component.

questions.question: What are the modes of ViewEncapsulation?
questions.answer: Emulated (default), None, and ShadowDom.

questions.question: What is Content Projection?
questions.answer: A way to insert, or project, the content you want to use inside another component using <ng-content>.

questions.question: What is @Input?
questions.answer: A decorator that marks a class field as an input property and supplies configuration metadata.

questions.question: What is @Output?
questions.answer: A decorator that marks a class field as an output property and supplies configuration metadata.

questions.question: What is EventEmitter?
questions.answer: Use in components with the @Output directive to emit custom events synchronously or asynchronously.

questions.question: What is ViewChild?
questions.answer: Property decorator that configures a view query.

questions.question: What is ContentChild?
questions.answer: Property decorator that configures a content query.

questions.question: What is the HostListener decorator?
questions.answer: Decorator that declares a DOM event to listen for, and provides a handler method to run when that event occurs.

questions.question: What is the HostBinding decorator?
questions.answer: Decorator that marks a DOM property as a host-binding property and supplies configuration metadata.

questions.question: What is a Pipe?
questions.answer: A class with the @Pipe decorator that transforms data for display in a template.

questions.question: Difference between Pure and Impure Pipes?
questions.answer: Pure pipes execute only when a pure change is detected. Impure pipes execute on every component change detection cycle.

questions.question: What is the AsyncPipe?
questions.answer: Unwraps a value from an asynchronous primitive (Promise/Observable).

questions.question: What is *ngIf?
questions.answer: A structural directive that conditionally includes a template based on the value of an expression.

questions.question: What is *ngFor?
questions.answer: A structural directive that renders a template for each item in a collection.

questions.question: What is trackBy in *ngFor?
questions.answer: A function that returns a unique identifier for each item, improving performance by reducing DOM manipulations.

questions.question: What is ng-template?
questions.answer: An Angular element for rendering HTML. It is never displayed directly.

questions.question: What is ng-container?
questions.answer: A logical container that can be used to group nodes but is not rendered in the DOM tree.

questions.question: How to pass data between sibling components?
questions.answer: Using a shared service with Observables (BehaviorSubject) or via a parent component.

questions.question: What is Change Detection Strategy?
questions.answer: Defines how Angular checks for changes. Default (CheckAlways) vs OnPush.

questions.question: What is a Provider?
questions.answer: An instruction to the DI system on how to obtain a value for a dependency.

questions.question: What is 'providedIn: root'?
questions.answer: Specifies that the service should be provided in the root injector (singleton).

questions.question: What are the different types of injectors?
questions.answer: ModuleInjector and ElementInjector.

questions.question: What is Hierarchical Dependency Injection?
questions.answer: Angular's DI system is hierarchical, meaning injectors form a tree that mimics the component tree.

questions.question: What is the @Injectable decorator?
questions.answer: Marks a class as available to be provided and injected as a dependency.

questions.question: What is the difference between @Injectable() and @Component() regarding DI?
questions.answer: Components are also injectable, but @Injectable is specifically for services that might have their own dependencies.

questions.question: How do you restrict DI resolution?
questions.answer: Using resolution modifiers: @Optional(), @Self(), @SkipSelf(), @Host().

questions.question: What is the purpose of @Self()?
questions.answer: Tells DI to look for the dependency only in the local injector.

questions.question: What is the use of InjectionToken?
questions.answer: Creates a token that can be used in a DI Provider, useful for non-class dependencies.

questions.question: What is a Tree-shakable provider?
questions.answer: A provider defined via providedIn: 'root' allowing unused services to be removed from the final bundle.

questions.question: What is the RouterModule?
questions.answer: A separate NgModule that provides the necessary service providers and directives for navigating through application views.

questions.question: What is <router-outlet>?
questions.answer: A directive that acts as a placeholder where the router should display the view for that outlet.

questions.question: What are Router Guards?
questions.answer: Interfaces that can tell the router whether to allow navigation to or from a route.

questions.question: List common Router Guards.
questions.answer: CanActivate, CanActivateChild, CanDeactivate, Resolve, CanLoad (deprecated in v15+ for CanMatch).

questions.question: What is Lazy Loading?
questions.answer: Loading NgModules or Standalone Components on demand instead of at startup.

questions.question: How do you define a route with a parameter?
questions.answer: { path: 'hero/:id', component: HeroDetailComponent }

questions.question: Difference between Template-Driven and Reactive Forms?
questions.answer: Template-driven relies on directives in the template; Reactive uses an explicit model in the component class.

questions.question: What is FormControl?
questions.answer: Tracks the value and validation status of an individual form control.

questions.question: What is FormGroup?
questions.answer: Tracks the same values and status for a collection of form controls.

questions.question: What is FormBuilder?
questions.answer: A service that provides syntactic sugar for creating instances of FormControl, FormGroup, or FormArray.

questions.question: What is RxJS?
questions.answer: A library for reactive programming using Observables that makes it easier to compose asynchronous or callback-based code.

questions.question: What is an Observable?
questions.answer: A stream of events or values over time.

questions.question: Difference between Promise and Observable?
questions.answer: Promise is single value, not cancellable. Observable is multiple values, cancellable, and lazy.

questions.question: What is a Subject?
questions.answer: A special type of Observable that allows values to be multicasted to many Observers.

questions.question: What is BehaviorSubject?
questions.answer: A Subject that requires an initial value and emits its current value to new subscribers.

questions.question: What is Subscription?
questions.answer: Represents the execution of an Observable, used to cancel the execution.

questions.question: What is the map operator?
questions.answer: Transforms each value emitted by the source Observable.

questions.question: What is switchMap?
questions.answer: Projects each source value to an Observable which is merged in the output Observable, emitting values only from the most recently projected Observable.

questions.question: What is mergeMap (flatMap)?
questions.answer: Projects each source value to an Observable which is merged in the output Observable.

questions.question: How to handle HTTP errors in Angular?
questions.answer: Using the catchError operator in the Observable pipe.

questions.question: What are Standalone Components?
questions.answer: Components that don't need to be declared in an NgModule. They simplify the mental model of Angular.

questions.question: How to create a standalone component?
questions.answer: Set 'standalone: true' in the @Component metadata.

questions.question: What is the inject() function?
questions.answer: A function that can be used to inject dependencies in a constructor or field initializer, usable outside of classes in certain contexts.

questions.question: What are Signals?
questions.answer: A system that granularly tracks how and where your state is used throughout an application, allowing the framework to optimize rendering updates.

questions.question: How do you define a Signal?
questions.answer: count = signal(0);

questions.question: How do you update a Signal?
questions.answer: count.set(5) or count.update(v => v + 1).

questions.question: What is a Computed Signal?
questions.answer: A signal that derives its value from other signals. double = computed(() => this.count() * 2).

questions.question: What is an Effect?
questions.answer: An operation that runs whenever one or more signal values change.

questions.question: What is Hydration in Angular?
questions.answer: The process that restores the server-side rendered application on the client. Destructive hydration was replaced by non-destructive hydration in v16.

questions.question: What are Required Inputs?
questions.answer: Allows inputs to be marked as required via @Input({ required: true }).

questions.question: What is TestBed?
questions.answer: The primary API for writing unit tests for Angular applications and libraries.

questions.question: What is Ahead-of-Time (AOT) compilation?
questions.answer: Compiles your app at build time. Default in modern Angular.

questions.question: What is Just-in-Time (JIT) compilation?
questions.answer: Compiles your app in the browser at runtime.

questions.question: What is Ivy?
questions.answer: The code name for Angular's next-generation compilation and rendering pipeline (default since v9).

questions.question: What is the difference between shallow and deep testing?
questions.answer: Shallow testing isolates the component (using NO_ERRORS_SCHEMA), while deep testing includes child components.

questions.question: What is Protractor vs Cypress/Playwright?
questions.answer: Protractor was the legacy E2E tool. Cypress and Playwright are modern alternatives.

questions.question: How to optimize Angular app performance?
questions.answer: Lazy loading, OnPush change detection, using trackBy, AOT, tree-shaking, optimizing bundles.

questions.question: What is the purpose of NgZone?
questions.answer: An injectable service for executing work inside or outside of the Angular zone.

questions.question: What is runOutsideAngular?
questions.answer: A method to run code without triggering Angular's change detection.

questions.question: What is Server-Side Rendering (SSR)?
questions.answer: Rendering pages on the server to improve initial load time and SEO (Angular Universal).

questions.question: What are Dynamic Components?
questions.answer: Components created at runtime using ViewContainerRef.

questions.question: What is Module Federation?
questions.answer: Allows loading code from other separately compiled builds (Micro-frontends).

questions.question: What is an Interceptor?
questions.answer: Inspects and transforms HTTP requests or responses between the app and the server.

questions.question: What is Multi-Provider?
questions.answer: Allows multiple providers to be associated with the same token (multi: true).

questions.question: What is APP_INITIALIZER?
questions.answer: A DI token that you can use to provide one or more initialization functions.

questions.question: What is ControlValueAccessor?
questions.answer: An interface that acts as a bridge between the Angular forms API and a native element in the DOM.

questions.question: What is CDK (Component Dev Kit)?
questions.answer: A set of behavior primitives for building UI components (DragDrop, Overlay, etc.).

questions.question: How does Angular Change Detection work?
questions.answer: It traverses the component tree checking for changes in bound properties. It uses zones to know when to check.

questions.question: What is the difference between Constructor and ngOnInit?
questions.answer: Constructor is for class initialization (dependency injection). ngOnInit is for Angular-specific initialization (input bindings available).

questions.question: What are Deferrable Views (@defer)?
questions.answer: A declarative way to defer loading of template dependencies (introduced in v17).
